Setting caps on hospital bills may inadvertently encourage wasteful consumption, like ordering more tests than necessary, because any expenses above the cap will be "free" to the patients. However, they have to be paid for ultimately by all of us, through higher taxes or premiums. Hence, it is better to have claim limits to help manage the cost of treatment, and instead, provide help to ensure that patients are able to pay for their bills.

Patients can tap on Medisave to pay for their share of the hospital bill, after subsidies and insurance payouts. For those with financial difficulties, they can approach the medical social workers to apply for assistance such as Medifund. This will ensure that health care will remain affordable.

takesSectionVOList.title: Water and Electricity Charges
takesSectionVOList.content:
28 Mr Seah Kian Peng asked the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources (a) when was the last time the price of water was increased for households and how this compares with the frequency and quantum of the rise in electricity tariffs; (b) what are the governing principles used in determining the rates for water and electricity; (c) whether the price of water is currently set on the basis of price recovery; and (d) what is the long-term marginal cost of water.

Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: The price of potable water in Singapore is pegged to the Long Run Marginal Cost (LRMC) of producing desalinated water and NEWater. Desalination and recycling are the main source of the next available drop of water given our shortage of land. Consequently, the water tariff and Water Conservation Tax reflect the true scarcity value of water.

The price of water has remained unchanged since 2000. Although labour and equipment costs have risen during these 15 years, PUB has been able to keep the LRMC relatively stable because of improvements in membrane technology and productivity. We should bear in mind that desalination and recycling water are energy intensive processes. Hence, the key variable for the future is the price of energy. Nonetheless, given the current state of technology and energy prices, there is no need for an adjustment at this point.

takesSectionVOList.title: Annual Caps on Subsidies for Chronic Disease Management Programme
takesSectionVOList.content:
31 Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song asked the Minister for Health in 2012, 2013 and 2014, how many eligible patients reached (i) the annual withdrawal cap of $400 from their own Medisave accounts (not that of their family members); or (ii) the annual CHAS subsidy limits of $320 or $480 for simple chronic (Tier 1) or complex chronic (Tier 2) conditions respectively, for treatment of conditions under the Chronic Disease Management Programme (CDMP).

Mr Gan Kim Yong: Subsidies at the specialist outpatient clinics, polyclinics and participating General Practitioner (GP) clinics under the Community Health Assistance Scheme (CHAS) help to ensure that outpatient care is affordable. Medisave use is sized primarily to help Singaporeans pay for subsidised hospitalisation costs. Its use has been extended to outpatient treatment of chronic diseases under the Chronic Disease Management Programme (CDMP) to help patients to defray their cash payment for such treatments.

Under the CDMP, up to $400 per year per Medisave account can be used for the treatment of 19 chronic conditions. The annual Medisave limit is reviewed regularly and was last increased in January 2012 from $300 to $400 per year. In 2014, about 5% of the 200,000 subsidised patients, or about 10,000 patients, fully utilised the annual $400 limit from their own Medisave accounts, up from 3% in 2012. This includes patients seeking care at the specialist outpatient clinics, polyclinics and CHAS GP clinics.

At CHAS GP clinics, patients can receive subsidies for the 19 CDMP chronic conditions under CHAS and Pioneer Generation (PG) packages. Generally, patients can be expected to co-pay for part of their treatment, with the lower-income and Pioneers paying less. In 2014, less than 2% of the 1.2 million CHAS members used up to their annual cap of chronic subsidy, similar to that in 2012 and 2013.

Outpatient subsidies were enhanced recently, together with additional subsidies for Pioneers to help reduce the amount that patients need to pay using their own Medisave or cash. Pioneers also have a higher CHAS subsidy limit than other CHAS beneficiaries. In addition, since April 2015, elderly have been able to use an additional $200 of Medisave a year to pay for various outpatient treatment, under the Flexi-Medisave scheme. These measures will help to reduce the number of patients, especially the elderly patients, who will exhaust their limits. My Ministry will continue to review the Medisave and CHAS limits regularly to ensure that outpatient care remains affordable.

takesSectionVOList.title: Revision of Fees Charged by Public Healthcare Groups
takesSectionVOList.content:
32 Er Dr Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for Health given that from time to time healthcare services run by public healthcare groups may revise the fees for their services (a) how many price revisions have there been in the past three years; (b) whether these institutions have to justify to the Ministry before revising such fees; (c) whether there is a standing procedure for these institutions to announce and explain such fee revisions to the public; and (d) whether the Ministry ensures that the public is adequately informed of any fee revisions instead of discovering such revisions only when they pay for their medication and treatment.

Mr Gan Kim Yong: The public healthcare institutions review their fees, like hospital ward charges, consultation fees and emergency department charges, from time to time. Where necessary, fees are adjusted and the adjustments may be implemented at different times for different institutions. Such fee revisions take into account changes in operating costs and enable the institutions to maintain and enhance their quality of care and service to patients.

The public healthcare institutions revise their fees only after careful consideration, and MOH works with the public healthcare institutions to minimise the impact on patients.

The public healthcare institutions also adopt several measures to ensure that patients are adequately informed of the fee revisions. For example, the public healthcare institutions generally display their revised fees on their websites and also at the clinics and registration counters. They also highlight the fees during the financial counselling process where relevant. They advise patients of the fee revisions, whenever patients visit or are admitted soon after the fee revision.

MOH recently enhanced subsidies at the specialist outpatient clinics and the polyclinics for the low- to middle-income families and Pioneers, to reduce the cost of subsidised treatment for them. Subsidised patients with financial difficulties can also approach the medical social workers to apply for assistance such as Medifund.

takesSectionVOList.title: Conversion of Land Use in Rivervale Crescent
takesSectionVOList.content:
34 Ms Lee Li Lian asked the Minister for National Development (a) what are the reasons for converting an empty piece of land in Rivervale Crescent from a secondary school development to a mix of a park and residential estate; and (b) whether this can be opened up for other types of development.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan: The land parcel at Rivervale Crescent was originally safeguarded for a primary school.

In 2013, the Urban Redevelopment Authority and Ministry of Education reviewed the distribution of school sites in Singapore. They concluded that there were sufficient primary schools in and around the Rivervale area, including Rivervale Primary School and North Spring Primary School.

URA thus rezoned the land parcel for other uses. A portion of the parcel has been set aside for a park to provide a green space for residents to enjoy. The rest of the parcel has been rezoned for residential use, which is compatible with the predominantly residential nature of Rivervale Crescent.

URA has considered other uses for the site but assessed that the residential use is the most compatible with surrounding developments.

takesSectionVOList.title: Utilisation Rates of City Direct and Feeder Bus Services
takesSectionVOList.content:
35 Mr Gan Thiam Poh asked the Minister for Transport (a) what are the current utilisation rates of City Direct bus services and feeder bus services operated by private bus operators respectively; (b) how many buses have been provided for each route of service; and (c) whether LTA can consider increasing the number of City Direct bus services for Hougang Avenue 8, Sengkang and Punggol.

Mr Lui Tuck Yew: So far, 10 City Direct Services and 14 Peak Period Short Services operated by private bus operators have been introduced as part of the Bus Service Enhancement Programme (BSEP). Altogether, 80 buses are deployed across these 24 bus services. The average ridership per trip is around 40-50 passengers for the City Direct Services, and around 30 passengers for the Peak Period Short Services. 12 more City Direct Services will be introduced by next year, including 3 new services to serve Punggol, Sengkang and Hougang towns.

takesSectionVOList.title: Provision in Government Contract for Emergency Bus Services in Event of Rail Disruptions
takesSectionVOList.content:
36 Mr Zaqy Mohamad asked the Minister for Transport (a) whether there are provisions in the Government Contracting Model (GCM) for buses in 2016 to be called up for emergency bus services in the event of rail disruptions; (b) whether the bill for these emergency bus services will be passed on to the rail operators; and (c) between the various bus operators under the GCM model, whether LTA has a plan on which operators will be tapped on to operate which emergency routes in a rail disruption.

Mr Lui Tuck Yew: In the event of a rail disruption, the rail operator is responsible and pays for free bus boarding near an affected station, and this will continue after the transition to bus contracting. These include all public bus services at designated bus stops and bus bridging services to ferry commuters between affected train stations. The rail operator is required to pre-arrange these services with bus operators. There are provisions in our bus contracts to support these arrangements.

takesSectionVOList.title: Employment Pass Applications Submitted immediately after 14-day Mandatory Advertisement Period in Jobs Bank
takesSectionVOList.content:
37 Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song asked the Minister for Manpower what is the number and percentage of Employment Pass (EP) applications since the launch of the Jobs Bank that have been submitted within one week of the end of the minimum 14-day mandatory advertisement period.

Mr Lim Swee Say: Under the Fair Consideration Framework (FCF) introduced on 1 August 2014, employers are required to advertise their job vacancies on the Jobs Bank for at least 14 days before they can submit applications for Employment Passes. Based on a weekly average, there are about 68,000 job vacancies posted on the Jobs Bank since it was launched in July 2014. 74% of these job vacancies, or about 50,000 jobs, are at the level of professionals, managers, executives, technicians and associate professionals (PMET). On average, 800 EP applications were received per week following their job advertisement. Out of which, about one-third were submitted within one week of the end of the 14-day mandatory advertising period.

As mentioned in the July sitting of this House, MOM has taken action to scrutinise more closely applications for EPs from these firms which are “double-weak” - weak in Singaporean core; and weak in commitment to fair consideration for Singaporeans, such as firms which repeatedly submit EP applications soon after the end of the minimum 14-day advertising period.

As updated by my Ministry last week, we have engaged 150 firms over the past year and placed 38 of them on MOM’s Watchlist. About 100 more firms have also been identified for further assessment. They are the outliers in their respective industries such as Administration & Support, Construction, Infocomm, Finance & Insurance, Professional Services, Transportation & Storage and Wholesale Trade.

Firms placed on the Watchlist are subject to closer monitoring and scrutiny. These firms will be encouraged and guided to avenues and assistance available to help them strengthen their Singaporean core, including help to train and equip Singaporeans with the skills and expertise to progress in their careers. Firms which are unresponsive or uncooperative can expect to have their work pass privileges curtailed.

To reiterate, FCF is part of a broader effort to improve employment outcomes of Singaporean PMEs, which have remained healthy. Singaporean PME unemployment remains low at 2.7% in 2014, and their real median wages grew at 3.8% per annum in the last five years. We are committed to further strengthening employment support for our Singaporean PMEs, and strive for a stronger Singaporean core in every major sector of the economy.

takesSectionVOList.title: Channelling Unemployed Citizens to Manpower-constrained Growth Sectors
takesSectionVOList.content:
38 Mr Thomas Chua Kee Seng asked the Minister for Manpower whether the Ministry will consider stepping up initiatives to facilitate the channelling of unemployed citizens to business growth sectors that are continuing to look for manpower.

Mr Lim Swee Say: Our unemployment rate remains low and employment rate high. Our local workforce growth is expected to slow down going forward. My Ministry therefore welcomes the Member’s suggestion to match unemployed citizens to available jobs in the growth sectors. These efforts would also benefit Singaporeans who are entering the workforce, and those currently employed but are seeking better job opportunities and career prospects in growth sectors.

Through its career centres, WDA and the Employment and Employability Institute (e2i) provide a suite of career services and employment facilitation efforts to match jobseekers to employment opportunities in various sectors, in particular the growth sectors. For the longer term, the Sectoral Tripartite Committees are formulating manpower plans for their respective sectors. This will identify the jobs and careers of the future and the measures to equip Singaporeans, both employed and unemployed, with the necessary skills to take on these opportunities.

takesSectionVOList.title: Dispute Resolution for Tenants in HDB's Joint Singles Scheme
takesSectionVOList.content:
39 Mr David Ong asked the Minister for National Development (a) how quarrelling tenants under HDB's Joint Singles Scheme can have their disputes settled quickly; and (b) what help is currently available for those who find it impossible to co-rent their flat.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan: Living together requires mutual tolerance and understanding. Given the shared living arrangements, rental tenants should be considerate, and provide mutual care and support to each other. In the event of a dispute, HDB will advise them to settle their dispute amicably. Where necessary, HDB will enlist the help of the Residents Committees or the Community Mediation Centre to mediate.

Applicants are encouraged to look for someone they know, such as a relative or a friend, to jointly rent a flat. HDB will also provide them with a list of single applicants, or introduce them to other single tenants of a similar profile. Tenants may then contact these individuals before mutually agreeing to jointly rent a flat. HDB may allow a tenant to rent a flat on his own if there are extenuating circumstances, such as if the tenant has medical conditions.

takesSectionVOList.title: Commuters Switching from North East Line to Upcoming Downtown Line 2
takesSectionVOList.content:
40 Mr Gan Thiam Poh asked the Minister for Transport (a) what is the projected number of commuters who will switch from the North East Line to Downtown Line 2 and benefit from the commencement of operation in December 2015; (b) whether Downtown Line 3 will commence earlier than scheduled; and (c) whether the Ministry will consider extending Downtown Line 3 at Tampines to Punggol, Sengkang and Ang Mo Kio.

Mr Lui Tuck Yew: North East Line (NEL) commuters will enjoy greater connectivity to areas served by the Downtown Line Stage 2 (DTL2), as they can transfer via Little India station to reach the city centre, and schools, malls and recreational areas in the Bukit Timah area. Up to 20% of NEL commuters, or about 90,000, will benefit.

Downtown Line Stage 3 is on schedule to open in 2017 as planned. There are no plans to extend it to Punggol, Sengkang and Ang Mo Kio as DTL3 is intended to connect areas in the East that are not directly served by the MRT network today, such as Ubi, Kaki Bukit and Bedok Reservoir.

takesSectionVOList.title: Meeting Manpower Needs of Expanding Bus Network
takesSectionVOList.content:
41 Assoc Prof Randolph Tan asked the Minister for Transport (a) how has the Bus Service Enhancement Programme (BSEP) managed the increase in demand for manpower; (b) why the tight labour market does not appear to have delayed the deployment schedule of the BSEP; and (c) what is the Ministry's plans for coping with the future manpower needs of the expanding bus transport network infrastructure.

Mr Lui Tuck Yew: The tight labour market is indeed a challenge for the bus industry. To address this, a multi-pronged strategy is needed. To attract more local bus captains, both operators have raised entry level base monthly salaries by about $400 since the Bus Service Enhancement Programme (BSEP) commenced in 2012. They have also introduced the Progressive Wage Model to enhance career progression for bus captains and technicians.

To professionalise the industry, new bus captains are trained and certified under the Public Transport Singapore Workforce Skills Qualifications Framework. The Land Transport Authority, in consultation with the National Transport Workers’ Union, is also building bus depots and interchanges with better facilities and rest areas for bus captains and staff.

The Public Transport Tripartite Committee, comprising members from the Government, public transport operators and union, and chaired by Senior Minister of State for Finance and Transport, Mrs Josephine Teo, will continue to explore further measures to attract and retain good workers for the industry.

takesSectionVOList.title: Security Sector's Readiness to Implement Progressive Wage Model
takesSectionVOList.content:
42 Ms Irene Ng Phek Hoong asked the Minister for Manpower (a) what is the status of the security sector's readiness to implement the Progressive Wage Model (PWM) from 1 September 2016 given the need to meet training requirements and wage levels by then; (b) whether there are measures to assist security guards who fail to meet the training requirements, to meet the new standards or to transition to another industry; and (c) what measures will be taken to ensure that service buyers will support the anticipated cost increases when tendering for new contracts or renewing existing contracts under PWM.

Mr Lim Swee Say: The Security Tripartite Cluster (STC) announced its recommendations on the Progressive Wage Model (PWM) for the security industry in October 2014. The PWM wage and training requirements will be incorporated in the existing licensing framework for security agencies administered by the Police Licensing and Regulatory Department (PLRD). From 1 September 2016, security agencies which do not comply with the PWM requirements will not have their licences renewed.

Since the announcement of the PWM, members of the STC, including PLRD, the security industry associations, U Care Centre and the Union of Security Employees, have been actively engaging security agencies and service buyers to brief them on the PWM. In these briefings, security agencies have been advised to enrol their employees for training and to comply with the PWM requirements early, ahead of the 2016 deadline.

All current security officers will be able to remain in the industry and retain their rank of "Security Officer" under the PWM. They will not be compelled to transition to other industries. For those keen to progress through the ranks to take on greater job functions and responsibilities, they need to attend specific Workforce Skills Qualification (WSQ) training courses to gain the necessary skills.

The Singapore Workforce Development Agency (WDA) has been working closely with training providers and STC members to implement several measures to help the industry meet the training requirements. First, training capacity has been increased to accommodate up to 2,800 training places per month. The current monthly average take-up for PWM modules across all levels is about 200 training places.

Second, an Assessment Only Pathway (AOP) process will be provided to allow more experienced security officers who are proficient and familiar with the security operations to be certified, without having to go through training. Preparatory AOP sessions will be made available to familiarise AOP candidates with the certification process.

Third, WDA is working with its appointed security industry training providers, such as the Security Industry Institute (SII) under Temasek Polytechnic, to implement an integrated curriculum that incorporates technology and workplace learning, to improve training outcomes.

Fourth, to help security agencies overcome operational constraints in sending their employees for training, flexible training arrangements, such as weekend classes, accessible on-site training and bite-sized training, have been put in place. Service buyers can also complement these efforts by encouraging flexible work arrangements that enable security officers to attend training and assessments.

The STC also intends to showcase security agencies and security officers who have met their PWM training requirements during the upcoming Security Industry Conference next month. We want to commend these early adopters, and encourage the rest of the industry to begin working towards full PWM compliance.

Ms Ng has asked if efforts are being made to reach out to service buyers so they will support the anticipated cost increases associated with the PWM. The STC is doing so. Aside from briefings to security agencies, STC members have also been reaching out to service buyers to explain the implications of the PWM and the benefits to them arising from a better quality workforce and improved service standards. Funding schemes are also available to help defray the initial costs that service buyers face when tendering for new contracts or renewing their existing contacts under the PWM. For example, the Progressive Wage Incentive administered by the Employment and Employability Institute (e2i) provides grants of up to $150,000 for service buyers that best source from early adopters of the PWM.

The STC meets regularly to get updates from member agencies involved in the implementation of the PWM and to consider the need for further measures to promote awareness and facilitate compliance with the PWM requirements. MOM will work closely with MHA and our tripartite partners on the STC to ensure that the security sector is ready to implement the PWM by September 2016.

takesSectionVOList.title: Bringing Forward Roll-out of Progressive Wage Model for Landscape Workers
takesSectionVOList.content:
43 Mr K Karthikeyan asked the Minister for Manpower whether the Ministry can bring forward the implementation of the Progressive Wage Model for landscape workers to this year.

Mr Lim Swee Say: The Progressive Wage Model (or PWM) for landscape workers was announced by the Tripartite Cluster for the Landscape Industry (TCL) in April this year, and will be incorporated as a requirement in the Landscape Company Register (or LCR) administered by the National Parks Board. From June 2016, LCR-registered companies will be required to pay their resident landscape maintenance workers according to the PWM.

The Progressive Wage Model (or PWM) for landscape workers was announced by the Tripartite Cluster for the Landscape Industry (TCL) in April this year, and will be incorporated as a requirement in the Landscape Company Register (or LCR) administered by the National Parks Board. From June 2016, LCR-registered companies will be required to pay their resident landscape maintenance workers according to the PWM.

While the deadline for implementation of the PWM is one year away, progressive companies can move ahead to start adopting the PWM. Funding schemes are available to help incentivise early adoption of the PWM and defray the initial costs of doing so. For example, the Progressive Wage Incentive administered by the Employment and Employability Institute provides grants of up to $150,000 for service buyers that best source from early adopters of the PWM.

takesSectionVOList.title: Allowing Pioneer Generation Patients to Select Doctors at Specialist Outpatient Clinics
takesSectionVOList.content:
44 Mr Lim Biow Chuan asked the Minister for Health whether the Ministry will consider allowing Pioneer Generation patients to select their own doctors at Specialist Outpatient Clinics at public/restructured hospitals.

Mr Gan Kim Yong: Currently, subsidised patients in our Public Healthcare Institutions (PHIs) receive care from a team of doctors, led by a senior doctor. This is to ensure that the patients will receive appropriate team-based care and where necessary, the senior doctors in the team will attend to the patients. Patients who wish to choose a specific doctor will have to pay private rates.

The same principle applies to Pioneers. Pioneers who are receiving treatment at the subsidised Specialist Outpatient Clinics (SOC) in PHIs receive an additional 50% subsidy on the net bill for subsidised services and medications.

Pioneers who are currently private patients and wish to enjoy the Pioneer Generation subsidies at SOCs, can apply to switch to the subsidised SOC. As subsidised patients, they may not continue to see their current doctor, but they will receive appropriate care from a team of doctors.

takesSectionVOList.title: Effectiveness and Extension of Use of Bird-deterrent Gel
takesSectionVOList.content:
45 Ms Lee Li Lian asked the Minister for National Development what is the time frame required to evaluate the effectiveness of the bird-deterrent gel used recently by the Choa Chu Kang Town Council to tackle pigeon issues and whether this gel will be made available to other town councils.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan: In February 2015, AVA worked with the Choa Chu Kang Town Council on a bird-deterrent gel trial, to test the effectiveness of the gel in deterring roosting. The preliminary results were promising with a reduction in roosting and fewer cases of bird nuisance.

AVA is monitoring the long-term effectiveness of the gel, especially over the migratory bird season which is generally from August to April. AVA will be better able to assess whether the gel continues to deter the birds from roosting after the end of the current migratory season in April 2016.

If the gel is effective, AVA will work with Town Councils that are keen to use the gel as part of their long term management of bird-related nuisance. Interested Town Councils would have to pay for the installation of the gel and ensure its maintenance and upkeep.

takesSectionVOList.title: Increasing Bus Frequency to Rivervale Delta
takesSectionVOList.content:
46 Ms Lee Li Lian asked the Minister for Transport with the release of new BTO flats in Rivervale Delta, whether the Ministry will look into (i) providing more bus services apart from the current bus 371; and (ii) increasing the frequency of current bus service 371 to cater to the increase in demand in the area.

Mr Lui Tuck Yew: Service 371 was introduced in January 2014, as part of the Government’s Bus Service Enhancement Programme, to provide residents of the new Build-To-Order flats in Rivervale Delta with a direct connection to Sengkang MRT and Bus Interchange. The service currently operates at peak period headways of 10 minutes, and will be improved further to not more than 8 minutes by end-2016. Residents can also access the Rumbia LRT Station, and other bus services, such as Service 50 along Sengkang East Way, Services 62 and 85 along Sengkang East Drive, and Service 86 along Rivervale Drive, all of which are within a 5 to 10-minute walk.

takesSectionVOList.title: Effectiveness of Existing Fair Employment Guidelines in Protecting Older PMEs
takesSectionVOList.content:
48 Mrs Lina Chiam asked the Minister for Manpower (a) whether the guidelines of the Tripartite Alliance for Fair and Progressive Employment Practices (TAFEP) are adequate to protect older workers since PMETs accounted for 51% of the layoffs last year; and (b) whether there is a need to legislate policies to safeguard the interest of these workers.

Mr Lim Swee Say: Under the Retirement and Re-employment Act, it is already an offence to dismiss an employee who is below the age of 62 years on the grounds of age. Employers are obliged to offer re-employment to their employees who are turning 62 up till age 65. If employers are not able to offer re-employment, they are required to make an Employment Assistance Payment to the workers, based on the quantum recommended by the Tripartite Guidelines on the Re-employment of Older Employees. In year ending June 2014, nearly all (99%) employees who turned 62 were offered re-employment. We are also looking to raise the re-employment age to 67 in the next two to three years.

Having said this, more needs to be done to change the mindsets of employers against ageism. This requires determined and sustained efforts by companies, co-workers and the community. Tripartite partners, through the Tripartite Alliance for Fair & Progressive Employment Practices (TAFEP), will continue in our efforts to help employers build capabilities and reinforce positive perceptions of older workers. The "Tap into a Wealth of Experience" campaign launched by the Tripartite Committee on Employability of Older Workers in June 2014 has resulted in some positive mindset changes amongst employers and older employees.

The Government also adopts a two-pronged approach to support older workers. First, the Special Employment Credit, or SEC, provides subsidies to employers to hire older workers. Today, employers receive an SEC of up to 8.5% of the wages of every Singaporean employee aged above 50 earning up to $4,000 per month. The SEC was further enhanced at Budget 2015 to provide employers with an additional 3%-point of wage subsidy for hiring Singaporean workers aged 65 and above, ie, up to a total of 11.5% of wages.

Second, there are measures in place to help older PMEs re-skill and secure new employment. We currently support employers who hire mature PMEs in Professional Conversion Programmes (PCP) by funding 90% of their monthly salary, subject to a cap of $4,000, during the period of training. The P-Max programme also supports the entry of PMEs into suitable jobs in our small and medium-sized enterprises.

In addition, we have recently announced the Career Support Programme (CSP) to provide mature Singaporean PMEs, who have been looking for jobs for at least six months, greater opportunities to access mid-level and above jobs. Starting from 1 October 2015, employers who employ mature PMEs, who have been looking for jobs for at least six months, in mid-level jobs that pay at least $4,000, will be given wage support. The Singapore Workforce Development Agency (WDA) will also collaborate with and provide incentives to private search and placement firms to help this group of older PMEs access more job opportunities.

We encourage employers to take full advantage of these schemes.

takesSectionVOList.title: Flats that have Benefitted from Home Improvement Programme
takesSectionVOList.content:
50 Mr David Ong asked the Minister for National Development (a) to date, what is the proportion of eligible flats that have completed the Home Improvement Programme (HIP); and (b) whether there are changes to the implementation date of HIP for the remaining eligible flats.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan: The Home Improvement Programme (HIP) was introduced in 2007 with about 300,000 eligible flats. Since then, HIP has been announced for 140,000 flats. We have completed the HIP works in 41,000 flats, while works for another 66,000 flats are in progress.

Last year, we announced the ramp up of HIP from 35,000 to 50,000 flats a year. We have selected another 100,000 flats for implementation in 2015 and 2016. With the ramp-up, HDB expects to complete selection of all eligible flats by 2018.

takesSectionVOList.title: 360-degree Feedback Appraisal System for Singapore-incorporated Companies
takesSectionVOList.content:
51 Mrs Lina Chiam asked the Minister for Manpower (a) whether the Ministry will consider implementing a 360-degree feedback appraisal system as a statutory requirement under the Employment Act for all Singapore-incorporated companies; and (b) if so, whether the results can be uploaded onto the Jobs Bank for public scrutiny.

Mr Lim Swee Say: The Employment Act stipulates basic terms and conditions of employment, and the rights and responsibilities of employers and employees.

We encourage companies to explore using tools such as 360-degree feedback to enhance their in-house human resource (HR) capabilities. However, we have no plans to mandate the use of any particular tool nor to require making their results public.

It is for companies to choose the HR tools most relevant to their needs and circumstances, not the Government. Moreover, confidentiality of the results of such tests and surveys is often key to soliciting candid feedback. Posting the results in the Jobs Bank runs counter to this.

takesSectionVOList.title: Overseas Singaporeans Registered as Overseas Voters
takesSectionVOList.content:
1 Mrs Lina Chiam asked the Prime Minister (a) what is the current number of overseas Singaporeans registered as overseas voters and the percentage of these voters when computed against the total number of eligible Singaporean voters; and (b) what is the percentage of eligible overseas voters who did not cast their votes during the last General Election in 2011.

Mr Teo Chee Hean (for the Prime Minister): As of 31 July 2015, 3,104 electors have registered to vote overseas. This is 0.1% of the total number of electors in the registers.

At the 2011 General Election, 78% of registered overseas electors cast their vote at the overseas polling stations.

takesSectionVOList.title: Update on Financial and Capital Market Integration in ASEAN
takesSectionVOList.content:
2 Mr Yee Jenn Jong asked the Prime Minister what has been the progress on financial and capital market integration in ASEAN under the ASEAN Economic Community and specifically whether Singapore will support the proposal for a Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSME) Growth Bank.

Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam (for the Prime Minister): The ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) will be launched at the end of 2015.

Financial integration is an important part of the AEC. It will support economic growth in the region, strengthen our financial markets, and promote financial inclusion. Good progress has been made but the pace of financial integration has generally lagged behind trade integration. Financial integration is complex as it involves issues of harmonising national regulatory standards, market conduct practices, disclosure requirements, and conditions of licensing. Further development and convergence in financial system maturity among the ASEAN economies would also aid the pace of financial integration.

Notwithstanding the slower pace of financial integration, there has been progress in the areas of banking, insurance, and capital markets.

For example in banking, ASEAN countries have established the ASEAN Banking Integration Framework (ABIF), which provides a platform for two or more ASEAN countries to agree on specific areas for liberalisation based on ASEAN banks’ commercial interests. The banks that meet ASEAN members’ respective admission criteria and prudential requirements will be able to enjoy greater market access and operational flexibility in the region.

As there are presently limited details on the proposed Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSME) Growth Bank, it is premature to decide on Singapore’s support for the proposal. However, our surveys indicate that the SME loan and equity financing programmes offered by private financial institutions have been broadly effective in meeting the financing needs of SMEs.

takesSectionVOList.title: Nomination of Full-time Employees of Statutory Boards for Election as MPs
takesSectionVOList.content:
3 Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song asked the Prime Minister whether full-time employees of statutory boards are considered to be holders of a whole time office in the service of the Government and be disqualified from being Members of Parliament (MP) or being nominated for candidacy for election as an MP.

Mr Teo Chee Hean (for the Prime Minister): The Constitution does not disqualify Statutory Board employees from running for office or becoming Members of Parliament as Statutory Boards are regarded in law as distinct entities from the Government.

Most Statutory Boards have nonetheless aligned their practice to that of the Civil Service. Employees of these Statutory Boards are not allowed to hold office in political parties and stand for election to Parliament.

For a small group of Statutory Boards which are not involved in policy formulation or implementation, such as institutions of higher learning, there is greater flexibility in the guidelines on participation in political activities. Employees of these Statutory Boards are generally allowed to join political parties and stand for election to Parliament unless they hold leadership positions in these entities.

takesSectionVOList.title: Deployment of Paramedics and Permissible Emergency Response Time
takesSectionVOList.content:
4 Mr K Karthikeyan asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs what is the current number of paramedics assigned to every fire station and whether that is derived from the ratio of citizens in the vicinity.

5 Mr K Karthikeyan asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs what is the permissible response time for ambulances to reach patients after receiving an emergency call.

Mr Teo Chee Hean: Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) plans the locations of fire stations and fire posts, and the deployment of fire engines and ambulances based on factors such as population density and case load. This ensures that SCDF’s emergency resources are well distributed to respond quickly to emergencies. SCDF’s deployment of emergency response resources is not static, and is adjusted as necessary to ensure prompt and effective emergency response.

SCDF currently has a fleet of 50 emergency ambulances that is located across 15 fire stations. Each fire station would have between one and five ambulances. Each ambulance is staffed by a three-man crew comprising a paramedic and two Emergency Medical Technicians.

The nearest available emergency ambulance is dispatched to attend to emergency medical cases. SCDF aims to respond to 80% of all emergency medical calls within 11 minutes. In 2014, SCDF received 155,781 emergency medical calls and responded to 83% of the cases within 11 minutes.

SCDF recently launched the Save-a-Life initiative to enhance the community response to medical emergencies before the arrival of an ambulance. Under the initiative, SCDF will install more Automated External Defibrillators (AEDs) in public spaces such as HDB lift lobbies, build a network of trained community responders, and alert them to cardiac arrest cases in their immediate vicinity through the myResponder mobile app. This community response will complement SCDF’s emergency response and help to increase the overall survival rate of cardiac arrest cases in Singapore.

takesSectionVOList.title: Take-up Rate for Space in JTC and HDB Industrial Parks
takesSectionVOList.content:
6 Er Dr Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) what is the take-up rate for space in JTC and HDB industrial parks for the past three years; (b) whether there is more demand than supply for such space; and (c) whether there are plans to build more such parks.

Mr Lim Hng Kiang: The occupancy rate of JTC’s and HDB’s industrial facilities dropped from 97% in 2012 to 96% in 2013 and 94% in 2014. For the overall industrial space market, the occupancy rate fell from 93% in 2012 to 91% in 2014, following the Government’s release of more industrial land and space in recent years.

An average of about 1.8 million sqm of industrial space is expected to come on-stream each year in 2016 and 2017. This is higher than the average annual supply and demand of around 1.5 million sqm and 1.0 million sqm in the past three years. Of the upcoming industrial space, new JTC developments will contribute about 340,000 sqm. The projects include JTC Chemicals Hub @ Tuas View and JTC nanoSpace @ Tampines. The Government will continue to monitor the industrial property market closely and make available more space when necessary.

takesSectionVOList.title: Human Resource Needs of Local Funeral Industry
takesSectionVOList.content:
7 Ms Kuik Shiao-Yin asked the Minister for Manpower (a) what is the number of full time, part-time and casual labour employed in the local funeral industry from 2010 to 2014; (b) what is the Ministry's projected human resource needs of the funeral industry for the coming decade; and (c) how is the Ministry working with the Ministry of Education to set up mortuary science or funeral directing courses to ensure that human resource needs of Singapore's funeral industry for the next decade are being met.

Mr Lim Swee Say: The local funeral industry employs fewer than 1,000 employees, which is less than 0.1% of the total workforce. Employment for the sector has grown steadily at about 6% per annum in recent years.

Despite the small employment numbers, the industry provides essential services for our society. While we face an ageing population, life expectancies have also increased. We expect to have a sufficient pipeline of manpower to meet the demand for funeral services given the current employment growth rates.

The funeral services industry is one where employers have provided on-the-job training. We encourage the industry to step up, and take the initiative to work with their employees to identify and develop the skillsets that are needed. Government will provide the necessary support and would be happy to work with the industry association to help support their training efforts.

takesSectionVOList.title: Sharing List of Eligible Bargainable Employees with Unions
takesSectionVOList.content:
8 Mr K Karthikeyan asked the Minister for Manpower whether the Ministry will review the sharing of the list of eligible bargainable employees with unions which was previously allowed but not allowed recently.

Mr Lim Swee Say: To facilitate the conduct of a secret ballot for union recognition under the Industrial Relations Act, the employer is required to provide to the Commissioner for Labour relevant information of the employees who are eligible to vote. This information is then verified by the union in the presence of the employer and the Commissioner. We recognise the importance of allowing the unions to verify the information and we will continue to do so.

takesSectionVOList.title: First-time Applicants Successful in Securing BTO Flats
takesSectionVOList.content:
9 Mr Gan Thiam Poh asked the Minister for National Development (a) in each of the past seven years to date, what is the number of first-time applicants who have been successful in securing their BTO flats; (b) how many of them have collected their keys in the past four years and how many are expected to collect their keys in 2015 and the next two years; and (c) how many of these first-timers have been successful in receiving grants for the purchase of HDB resale flats in the past seven years.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan: Since 2008, about 100,000 first-timer applicants, comprising families and singles, have bought a new HDB flat through a Build-to-Order (BTO) or Sale of Balance Flats (SBF) exercise:

Among these successful applicants, about 50,400 (50%) have collected the keys to their flats and 6,700 (7%) will be collecting theirs later this year. We expect another 31,100 (31%) to collect their keys in 2016 or 2017, and the balance 11,800 (12%) after 2017.

Over the same period, another 38,400 first-timer applicants were successful in receiving housing grants for the purchase of resale HDB flats.

takesSectionVOList.title: Raising Quota under Married Child Priority Scheme for Mature Estates
takesSectionVOList.content:
10 Ms Tin Pei Ling asked the Minister for National Development whether HDB will consider raising the quota under Married Child Priority Scheme for mature estates to encourage and better enable young couples to care for their elderly parents who are more likely to reside in mature estates.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan: In November 2014, HDB converted the Married Child Priority Scheme (MCPS) from being chance-based to quota-based. With the enhancement, young couples who are first-time buyers have a significantly higher chance of securing a flat in mature estates near their parents, as we set aside 30% of the flat supply for them.

In addition, among the MCPS applicants, we give first priority to two groups

i) Parents and married children who apply for a flat to live together under one roof in mature estates; and

ii) Parents who own a flat in mature estates applying for a flat in non-mature estates to live near their married child.

As land for new flats in mature estates is limited, first-timer couples could consider buying an HDB resale flat to live with or near their parents and receive the higher-tier CPF Housing Grant of $40,000, which is $10,000 higher than the basic-tier amount.

We are studying how we can further help those who wish to buy a resale flat near their parents. MND is committed to fostering strong families and enabling family members to live near one another for mutual care and support.

takesSectionVOList.title: Exemption from Mandatory Pre-packed Material Requirement for Home-owners Renovating BTO Flats
takesSectionVOList.content:
11 Ms Tin Pei Ling asked the Minister for National Development whether the Ministry will exempt home owners of MacPherson Residency who are renovating their BTO flats from the mandatory pre-packed material requirement given that a great majority of them have secured their units before the rule's introduction in 2014 and not all blocks could start renovation before 1 June 2015 due to the staggered key collection dates.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan: The requirement to use pre-packed waterproofing material for renovation of wet areas in HDB flats has been mandated since 2001. This requirement was extended to cover dry areas such as living rooms and bedrooms in view of the many benefits derived from the use of pre-packed material. They include higher quality of finished works, cleaner environment, higher productivity and lesser material wastage.

In June 2014, the HDB Registered Renovation Contractors (RRCs) were informed of the intention for the change. They had a year from then until implementation of policy to adjust and to advise their clients accordingly.

The mandatory requirement is consistently applied to all renovation carried out in existing and new HDB flats, regardless of the key collection dates.

takesSectionVOList.title: Repackaging and Sale of Fukushima Food Products under Local Brand Names
takesSectionVOList.content:
12 Mrs Lina Chiam asked the Minister for National Development (a) whether any Fukushima food products have been repackaged and sold under other local brand names in Singapore; (b) if so, what are these local brand names and in which supermarkets are these repackaged goods being sold; and (c) whether the Ministry will consider a research study on the health effects of Fukushima products on consumers.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan: The Agri-Food & Veterinary Authority of Singapore (AVA) licenses and registers all food importers and is able to impose import requirements on them. In addition to requiring each food consignment from Japan to be accompanied by a certificate of origin, stating which prefecture the food originates from, the food packaging also needs to be labelled with information, such as country of origin of food and contact information of the local importer. This is to ensure that the food products in the market are correctly labelled. To date, AVA’s active surveillance has not detected any case of Fukushima food products being mislabelled or repackaged and sold under other local brand names in Singapore.

AVA continues to test foods from Japan. Since January 2013, AVA has not detected any radioactive contamination in food samples from Japan. Hence it is not necessary to carry out a research on the health effects of Fukushima food products on local consumers. Singapore does not tolerate any radioactive contaminants in food.

takesSectionVOList.title: Season Parking Area for NEA-licensed Mobile Snack Food Vendors
takesSectionVOList.content:
13 Mr Zainal Sapari asked the Minister for National Development whether HDB can consider granting an area for season parking to enable NEA-licensed mobile operators who sell ice-cream, canned drinks and pre-packed tit-bits to continue their livelihood and help them manage their operation cost.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan: HDB car parks are provided primarily to serve the parking needs of the residents. Allowing commercial activities, such as the sale of food items, to be conducted in a dedicated season parking area could compromise the safety of the patrons and car park users, and may also cause dis-amenities to residents living in the area.

For these reasons, HDB has no plans to enable NEA-licensed mobile operators or other vendors to carry out their businesses in HDB car parks.

takesSectionVOList.title: Complaints from BTO and DBSS Flat Owners
takesSectionVOList.content:
14 Mr Yee Jenn Jong asked the Minister for National Development what is the number of complaints the Ministry has received from flat owners over the past years per 100 units of flats completed for (i) Built-to-Order (BTO) flats and (ii) Design, Build and Sell Scheme (DBSS) flats respectively.

Mr Khaw Boon Wan: On average, about one-third of new Build-to-Order (BTO) residents approach the Building Service Centre (BSC) for assistance after collecting their keys.

Design, Build and Sell Scheme (DBSS) projects are developed by different private developers who may offer varying fixtures and finishes for their project. DBSS projects are not standardised hence it is not meaningful to compare the rates of feedback on quality. Residents of DBSS developments who face issues with the quality of their flats may report them directly to the BSC managed by the developer during the one-year Defects Liability Period.

takesSectionVOList.title: Use of New Technology to Augment and Modernise SAF's Existing Fighting Force
takesSectionVOList.content:
15 Mr Christopher de Souza asked the Minister for Defence (a) how will the Ministry increase its use of new technology to augment and modernise the SAF's existing fighting force in the next 15 years in the backdrop of emerging threats like cyber attacks; and (b) whether he can elaborate on the rollout of the doubling of SAF's mobility and motorised functions.

Dr Ng Eng Hen: MINDEF/SAF continually leverages technology to keep the SAF sharp and to modernise its capabilities. Ensuring that the SAF remains a credible force against all prospective threats to Singapore for the future goes beyond type-for-type platform replacements. We are developing new innovative fighting concepts to fully exploit the potential of emerging technologies.

New technologies such as unmanned systems and robotics can multiply the combat effectiveness of our soldiers, allowing the SAF to overcome our constraints of a limited population. Our Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) systems, which can stay airborne for more than 24 hours, can already provide persistent, near real-time situational awareness to our forces. This allows the SAF to see further, in greater resolution, and fight more effectively. Out at sea, we have been conducting trials of Unmanned Surface Vessels (USVs), and successfully tested their ability to patrol our congested waterways. In the future, our ships paired with USVs can efficiently and effectively protect a far larger area to secure our sea lines of communications. There is great potential for such technologies on land as well. Unmanned Ground Vehicles (UGVs) may soon be used to conduct security patrols. With the UGVs, we could reduce the number of guards on patrol, yet protect larger areas. Moving forward, such UGVs could assist our soldiers in ensuring that key installations and infrastructure remain safe from the threat of attack.

Threats are also evolving in non-traditional domains, like cyber, and the SAF has to remain vigilant to guard against threats to our military networks. New units for cyber defence are being raised and our Cyber Defence Operations Hub (CDOH) is also being enhanced. Better capabilities using infocomm technology, artificial intelligence and big data analytics are in the pipe-line to enhance existing systems. Taken together, these capabilities will ensure that our networks are resilient with robust defence systems.

Even as we develop emerging technologies, we will continue to build upon the strong foundations of the 3rd Generation SAF’s transformation. The Army will be more mobile and capable, with the number of units operating on wheeled or tracked platforms almost doubling in the next 10-15 years. These units can influence areas up to three times larger, thereby multiplying the potency of our Army. This will include more Terrex Infantry Carrier Vehicles (ICVs) to deal with increasingly complex urban environments. Our first motorised infantry brigade, equipped with the Terrex ICVs, will achieve initial operating capability next year. The Army recently commissioned the new Peacekeeper Protected Response Vehicles. These vehicles will be networked with other SAF platforms so that they can collectively see more, see further and allow our soldiers to act more decisively. This significantly enhances the mobility, survivability, and firepower of our soldiers.

takesSectionVOList.title: Update on Construction of Downtown Line 2 MRT Stations at King Albert Park, Sixth Avenue and Tan Kah Kee
takesSectionVOList.content:
16 Mr Christopher de Souza asked the Minister for Transport (a) whether he can provide an update on the progress of construction of the Downtown Line 2 stations of King Albert Park, Sixth Avenue and Tan Kah Kee; and (b) whether these stations are on track to being operationalised by mid-2016.

Mr Lui Tuck Yew: Progress has been better than expected. Officers from the Land Transport Authority have worked very hard and innovatively with the new contractors to make up for the delay caused by the insolvency of the original contractor, Alpine Bau. Downtown Line 2 will now be opened on 27 December 2015, instead of first quarter of 2016 as earlier forecast.

takesSectionVOList.title: Expediting Completion of Downtown Line 2 MRT Stations to Keep within Timeline
takesSectionVOList.content:
17 Mr Christopher de Souza asked the Minister for Transport how was LTA able to expedite the completion of the Downtown Line 2 MRT stations ahead of schedule in December 2015 and make up for lost time such that the insolvency of the contractor Alpine Bau GmbH did not hamper the completion timeline.

Mr Lui Tuck Yew: The insolvency of Alpine Bau affected the completion timeline of three stations, Tan Kah Kee, Sixth Avenue and King Albert Park, and their associated tunnels. LTA and their contractors have worked hard to make up the lost time by mobilising resources from other completed DTL2 stations and extending work hours where possible. They also restructured the work processes and coordinated concurrent activities for the project where feasible.

For example, to expedite the testing and commissioning of the systems, LTA and their contractors carried out the works simultaneously on different parts of the line. To overcome the lack of cabling connection across the affected section to the Operation Control Centre (OCC) at Gali Batu Depot, a Local Control Centre was set up at Little India station to allow early commencement of testing for this stretch of the line.

takesSectionVOList.title: Extension of Downtown Line or Circle Line and Building of Cross Island Line
takesSectionVOList.content:
18 Mr Gan Thiam Poh asked the Minister for Transport whether LTA will consider (a) an extension of either the Downtown Line or Circle Line to connect to Pasir Ris, Punggol and Sengkang West; and (b) the building of the Cross Island Line from Changi through Pasir Ris and Punggol first.

Mr Lui Tuck Yew: Residents of Pasir Ris, Punggol and Sengkang West are already directly connected to the rail network via the East-West Line (EWL) and the North-East Line (NEL). The eastern stretch of the Downtown Line (DTL3) is designed to serve the corridor between the EWL and NEL that does not have access to the MRT network today. The Circle Line (CCL) is an orbital line that improves connectivity between the major radial lines. Extending the DTL or CCL to Pasir Ris, Punggol and Sengkang West would affect these primary objectives and sub-optimise their operations. The Cross Island Line is still in the study stage and more details will be provided when the study is completed.

takesSectionVOList.title: Measures to Minimise Traffic Noise Level along Central Expressway Facing Residential Homes
takesSectionVOList.content:
19 Mr Ang Hin Kee asked the Minister for Transport whether the Ministry will be implementing additional measures besides planting more trees and using more porous road mixtures to minimise the noise level arising from the expansion works and heavy vehicular traffic along stretches of the Central Expressway facing residential homes especially those near Seletar and Sunrise estates.

Mr Lui Tuck Yew: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) is currently trialling road noise barriers at four locations with high traffic volumes and noise levels, namely the Anak Bukit Flyover of the Pan-Island Expressway (PIE), the new flyover along Braddell Road, the West Coast Highway, and the section of the PIE next to Swiss View and Greenbank Park. The trials will allow LTA to evaluate the effectiveness and visual impact of noise barriers, as well as better understand the challenges in their installation, maintenance and design. Thereafter, LTA will consider the feasibility of installing such noise barriers at other locations.

takesSectionVOList.title: Extending MRT Network to Link Punggol to Yio Chu Kang and Seletar Towns
takesSectionVOList.content:
20 Mr Ang Hin Kee asked the Minister for Transport whether the Ministry has plans to extend the MRT networks to link Punggol directly to Yio Chu Kang and Seletar towns as these towns are currently only accessible by roads from Punggol and the population at neighbouring Sengkang has expanded.

Mr Lui Tuck Yew: Currently, commuter travel between Punggol and the Yio Chu Kang and Seletar towns can be sufficiently supported by buses. LTA is also studying the implementation of a new bus service to connect the north and north-east regions, as part of the Bus Service Enhancement Programme. As with other towns, LTA will continue to monitor travel demand and study the feasibility of new rail lines where necessary.

takesSectionVOList.title: Non-payment of Fares and Acts of Violence against Taxi Drivers
takesSectionVOList.content:
21 Er Dr Lee Bee Wah asked the Minister for Transport (a) how many cases of passengers refusing to pay their fares and committing acts of violence have been reported by taxi drivers in the past three years; (b) whether the Ministry will consider raising the penalties against such offenders to serve as a deterrence; and (c) whether the Ministry will make it mandatory for taxi drivers to be covered by insurance against loss of income and medical treatment arising from any injury sustained in such incidents.

Mr Lui Tuck Yew: Over the past three years, there were 355 cases of fare evasion and 162 cases of passengers assaulting taxi drivers.

Passengers found guilty of fare evasion may be fined up to $1,000, and repeat offenders may be fined up to $2,000 or jailed for up to six months, or both. Voluntarily causing hurt is a criminal offence under the Penal Code, and offenders can be fined up to $5,000 or jailed for up to two years, or both. Taxi drivers are also protected under the Protection from Harassment Act enacted last year, under which offenders face a fine not exceeding $5,000 or imprisonment not exceeding 12 months, or both. We assess that the penalties are appropriate for now, but will continue to review regularly.

We encourage all taxi drivers to take up appropriate medical and income insurance. However, on the question of whether we should make it mandatory, different drivers have different needs and some may decide that they do not need as much insurance as others. This is a decision best left to individual drivers.

takesSectionVOList.title: Family Service Centres Helping Intellectually Disabled Find Jobs
takesSectionVOList.content:
22 Ms Lee Li Lian asked the Minister for Social and Family Development (a) how do family service centres reach out to intellectually disabled individuals to help them find jobs; and (b) what is the success rate of helping them to secure jobs.

Mr Tan Chuan-Jin: In July 2013, the Ministry of Social and Family Development set up SG Enable, an organisation which will serve as a focal point to enable and serve persons with disabilities. Amongst its services, SG Enable supports persons with disabilities in their employment and training. Community touchpoints such as Family Service Centres and Social Service Offices can refer persons with disabilities, including persons with intellectual disabilities, to SG Enable for job referrals and job matching.

The referred persons will undergo work preparation and job-related training and receive job placement and support services offered by SG Enable and its Voluntary Welfare Organisation (VWO) partners, including the Movement for the Intellectually Disabled of Singapore (MINDS). In financial year 2014, SG Enable and its VWO partners placed more than 350 persons with disabilities in jobs. About one in three have intellectual disabilities.

takesSectionVOList.title: Suicides and Attempted Suicides in Singapore
takesSectionVOList.content:
23 Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song asked the Minister for Social and Family Development (a) what is the breakdown of suicides and attempted suicides in Singapore according to age, ethnicity, sex, and monthly income for the past five years; (b) whether the Government has conducted studies on suicide in Singapore and, if so, whether such studies can be made publicly available; and (c) whether the Government has introduced any measures or programmes to address suicide in Singapore.

Mr Tan Chuan-Jin: Between 2010 and 2014, there were an average of about 400 cases of suicides and 1,000 cases of attempted suicides each year. There were about twice as many males as females. The median age of persons committing suicide was 50.9 years in 2014. Chinese and Indians have higher suicide rates compared to Malays. Breakdown in terms of income is not available.

The causes of suicide are complex and multi-faceted. They could be due to a combination of factors related to relationship and family, social, economic and mental and physical health issues. These were also the common reasons of suicides identified in a locally published study.

Government agencies including MSF, MOH and HPB have funded and put in place efforts in public education, prevention and support. They have worked closely with voluntary welfare organisations (VWOs) on several of these efforts. In our schools for example, students are taught to set realistic goals for themselves, build healthy relationships with others and seek help where necessary. The Health Promotion Board has a peer support programme which trains selected tertiary students on mental health issues such as suicide prevention and peer support skills to reach out to their schoolmates. For the elderly, there are active ageing programmes to promote an active lifestyle and encourage socialisation. Senior Activity Centres provide befriending programmes, centre-based activities and home visits for needy elderly who live alone. Family Service Centres provide support to help individuals and families resolve their relationship, financial and emotional difficulties.

Healthcare and social service professionals play important roles in identifying and providing support to higher-risk individuals, especially those with a history of suicidal and self-harming behaviours. For persons who have attempted suicide, the first step is to eliminate acute suicide danger through hospitalisation and crisis-intervention, and follow-up care such as counselling and support groups.

The wider public can play a role in preventing suicides. The Samaritans of Singapore, which receives Community Chest funding, undertakes regular public education efforts to raise public understanding on suicides and the available avenues for help. It also runs a 24-hour crisis intervention and suicide prevention hotline. We can all play our part to raise awareness of suicides, reach out to those among us who may be at risk and refer those who need support to the services available.
